Column: 1846



    Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member): Sir, carrying on from where hon. Member Irene Ng left off yesterday, this cut on the abandoned babies has to do with the situation as we currently have. Given the existing law at the same time and our concern for the well-being of the abandoned babies, what can the Ministry do to help the community understand the issues and to find ways and means to help abandoned babies and their mothers and/or putative fathers so as to send a signal to the society at large that, while we do not condone the abandonment of babies, we would still help the expecting mothers and their babies and, where possible, their fathers too?

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, yesterday, my colleague spoke on the abandonment of babies and the need to provide a safe environment for them. I could not agree more because, each year, there are many couples who head for places elsewhere to look for babies to adopt. Yet, in Singapore, we have, on average, five or more abandoned babies each year. I was told there were five in 2002.

    Sir, there are many well-meaning Singaporeans out there who are more than happy to accept these children and we give them a safe and warm environment. They are prepared to give our babies a second chance. It is not for us to judge the morality of the parents who dump these children. There are reasons for wanting to abandon the babies, albeit anonymously. The law, as Prof. Ngiam has earlier pointed out, does not make it legal for anyone to abandon babies. They could be jailed for up to seven years and be fined. There are penal provisions like these, and we wonder why people are not leaving their babies at HDB doorsteps, or even offering babies for adoption at home.

    Sir, the Minister, in his recent reply, said that only a few jurisdictions allow for legal dropping of babies. I had wanted to ask the Minister if in these jurisdictions, the introduction of such legislation has resulted in an increase in the number of

Column: 1847

babies being abandoned. Even if it has, does it matter? The issue at hand is one of morality. Of course, it may be said that permitting mothers to drop their babies anonymously may encourage foreign workers to unlawfully get pregnant, and to choose baby abandonment as opposed to abortion as the preferred route to deal with the problem. I am referring here to the sex workers and work permit holders. The problem may be more apparent than real, as it can be dealt with administratively. We can require them to go for more regular check-ups to surface their pregnancy way before the full term. And this leaves us only with a very small segment of the population who could possibly get away with an unlawful pregnancy. My suspicion is that, as in the days when we tacitly allowed babies to be dropped at CHIJ, we may never have a greater number of abandoned babies than was the case previously. This baby drop was stopped sometime in the 1980s.

    I submit that allowing parents to anonymously leave their babies will allow for greater opportunity for counselling and advice since they will have the absolute assurance that the full weight of the law will not be thrown at them.

    We have to relook at our policies. The problem will not go away by denying the legality of baby drops. Think of the babies who have been abandoned in the previous year. One was left bloodied and naked, in a lift lobby at Sims Place. She was lying on newspapers and could have been easily mauled by stray dogs, attracted by the smell of the mother's blood fresh on the skin of the new-born baby. Another was left on the bench at the basement of KK Women's and Children's Hospital on a November evening. Yet, a third was found in a cardboard box in the lift landing of a block of flats in Tiong Bahru. Over the last month, we had two abandoned babies who died. How many more babies have to die before the Government will act?

    I do not personally think that there are compelling reasons not to allow legal baby drops for adoption.

Column: 1848



    The Chairman: Mr Sin, could you finish your speech soon?

    Mr Sin Boon Ann: Yes, I am finishing. I will just finish by saying that a life is a life no less, no matter what the colour is. I would urge the Minister to reconsider.

    The Acting Minister for Community Development and Sports (Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim): Sir, I would like to thank hon. Members who have spoken about our TFR and the need for us to look into the issue of abandoned babies.

    My Ministry defines its policy goal on family in a simple phrase: "More Strong and Stable Families". Short and sweet, to the point. Our policies are designed to be pro-family, pro-marriage and pro-children.

    Let me first talk about our policy goal of "More Families". Mr Charles Chong, Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon, Dr Jennifer Lee and Dr Maliki have asked about our marriage and birth trends. Sir, Members must well know that the birth rates have not been very encouraging in the past few years. The number of resident births fell to 38,700 in 2002, compared to 39,300 in 2001 and nearly 45,000 in 2000. The total fertility rate has continued to fall, from 1.6 in 2000 to 1.41 in 2001. Last year, it hit a record low of 1.37.

    In year 2000, the Prime Minister announced the Baby Bonus and the Third Child Paid Maternity Leave schemes. Together with these two schemes, we also introduced marriage and paternity leave in the civil service, and extended the childcare subsidy to non-working mothers. In 2002, the child sick leave was made available to male civil servants and extended to children up to 12 years old.

    The package of measures we introduced in 2000 takes a holistic approach, providing not only increased financial support, but also measures to strengthen childcare options, work-life practices as well as public education. Our approach has been to create a total social environment conducive to family and having children.

Column: 1849



    While my Ministry is concerned with the fall in fertility rates, we think that it would be too hasty to conclude that these initiatives are ineffective. Family policy, however well developed, requires a strong and stable economic environment to achieve its purpose of a stable or high TFR. Let me quote the experience of another country to explain. Between 1990 and 1993, Sweden suffered from an economic crisis. The Swedish GDP declined by 5%. At the same time, the number of jobs fell by nearly 10%. Along with the economic recession came the decline in TFR, from 2.14 in 1990 to 1.59 in 1996. Since then it has hovered around 1.5. Economic cycles and economic prospects impact fertility rates.

    For all we know, our birth rates could have been worse if not for the schemes that I mentioned earlier. Let me quote another example. Quebec introduced a baby bonus scheme, formally known as the Allowance for Newborn Children in 1988. After an initial rise in TFR, Quebec's TFR started falling. Many thought the scheme had failed. And in 1997, the scheme was removed.

    However, an empirical study published in 2002 by Kevin Milligan, an Associate Professor in Economics from the University of British Columbia, has a new perspective. Milligan says that Quebec's fertility rate was worse than the rest of Canada throughout the 1980s before the baby bonus. But after the baby bonus was introduced, the fertility gap between Quebec and the rest of Canada was reduced by 86%. Milligan estimates that the baby bonus probably resulted in an extra 93,000 births, over and above the births that would have taken place even if there was no baby bonus. This represented a 14.5% increase. While Milligan's study may not be the last word, it does serve to caution us against prematurely evaluating our policies. So let us not be in a hurry to throw the proverbial baby out with the bathwater.

    Singapore's baby bonus helps couples to defray part of the cost of bringing up their children. Couples can use the baby bonus to pay for infant care, childcare and

Column: 1850

kindergarten fees for all their children. As at the end of February 2003, some 31,800 children and 3,400 mothers have benefited from the Baby Bonus and Third Child Paid Maternity Leave schemes respectively. They received a total of $46 million under the Baby Bonus scheme. For the Third Child Maternity Leave, $18.8 million was disbursed for the same time period. Close to 90% of the families have co-saved into the Children's Development Account.

    Dr Jennifer Lee suggested that we study the European countries which have higher fertility rates. Indeed, some countries have bucked the trend of falling fertility. One example is Norway. Norway's total fertility rate has remained around 1.8 in the past 10 years. Another example is France. In 1993, France's total fertility rate was 1.66, but 10 years later, in 2002, total fertility rate had rebounded to 1.9, which is high among developed countries. The relatively high birth rates in both countries were often attributed to generous maternity and parental leave schemes, as well as family and child support. Interestingly, the CNA reported last month that Singaporeans living in the Cazaux Airbase in France are enjoying a baby boom!

    There are valuable lessons that we can learn. My Ministry is far from throwing in the towel. Instead, we are studying the policies implemented in those countries to see what we can learn and adapt to the local context. We, of course, have to bear in mind the culture and societal norms which enabled those policies to work in the countries I mentioned earlier. The challenge for Singapore is to replicate the successful policies of those countries in a different operating environment and culture.

    Sir, Dr Jennifer Lee also notes that immigration should not be the only solution to our falling fertility problem. I agree with her. Whilst we must continue to attract new citizens to top up our population, we must be mindful that many countries are also competing for them. My Ministry believes that the renewal of the local population will remain critical in Singapore.

Column: 1851



    Mr Charles Chong has suggested that there be an Inter-Ministerial Committee called Making Singaporeans Committee to arrest the decline of our TFR. I would like to assure the Member that the two existing committees that he mentioned will continue to consult our community partners and the public, particularly young married couples, in reviewing our policies to achieve that much needed breakthrough.

    More Singaporeans are marrying later. In 2002, the median age of marriage was 26.2 years for women and 28.9 years for men. In 1990, it was 25.3 years and 27.9 years respectively. At the same time, not many married couples would have their first child immediately. And if we are lucky, some may even consider having a second or even a third.

    Sir, this phenomenon is understandable. Our young, especially those who go on to tertiary education, spend a considerable amount of time studying. But once they start working, they want to focus on building their careers. Graduate women tend to start a family when they are 30 while those with post-secondary education are only slightly earlier, usually starting their family when they are about 29 years old. After all, multi-tasking is a favourite buzzword today, but when it comes to life goals, we seem to be single-mindedly single-tasking!

    Sir, those who wait longer would come across another barrier, and Dr Balaji has mentioned this earlier. This time it is mother nature. In a Straits Times' article on 3rd January 2003, Dr Christopher Chen from the Gleneagles Hospital estimates that 1 in 5 couples here face fertility problems. Conceiving at a later age reduces the opportunity to have more children as the fertility window is narrower.

    Sir, here I would like to cite my own personal example. I followed the model that I mentioned earlier. I met my wife in

Column: 1852

the US, got married, but both of us were studying and had our first child when I was 40 years old, after I had established my career in NUS and bought a home. We had our second child when I was 42 years old. If you ask me now whether we want to have a third child, my wife would say no, only because she is getting older. So, it is very difficult that, as we try to plan for our lives, we also have to understand that there are choices that we have to make and, as we make the choices much later, we actually reduce the opportunity for us to have a larger family. I came from a family of nine; I wish to have four.

    But how do we overcome this challenge? It is not easy, but we must try. As Mr Charles Chong rightly pointed out, there must be both monetary support and non-monetary incentives to help create a conducive environment for Singaporeans to have more children. So, we facilitate interactions through the SDU and SDS, introduce procreation measures to help couples to have more babies, and provide care services for the young ones, so that the parents can continue to build their careers.

    Mr Charles Chong and Dr Maliki have asked about the effectiveness of the Social Development Unit (SDU) and the Social Development Services (SDS).

    The SDU and SDS ran an operating budget of about $3.7 million in FY2002. Together, they have about 105,000 members. On average, about 2,500 social activities are run every year for over 74,000 participants. In addition, about 10,000 members actively participate in both the units' dating services.

    Sir, the proportion of married female graduates increased from about 44% in 1987, to 57% in 2001. Since its inception 19 years ago, I am happy to say that nearly 30,000 SDU members have gotten married. For SDS, more than 100,000 members have married since 1985. This is a success rate of about 55% of total SDS membership.

Column: 1853



    Dr Maliki asked if we do review the effectiveness of our SDU programmes in view of the changing profile of singles. Indeed, SDU reviews its programmes regularly to attract the interest of the changing needs of each cohort of singles. Towards the end of 2000, SDU outsourced the management of its socialisation activities to Premier Club, a private company. Since then, many new dating programmes have been introduced, including Speed Dating, Blind Dates, and Zodiac Dates, which have proven to be very popular. This positive change is evidenced by a 20% increase in the participation from members who were previously inactive.

    I share Dr Maliki's concern about marriage not being a priority among his students. From a survey conducted by my Ministry, 18% of couples met their partners at their workplace, while another 17% met them at school or university. Dr Maliki would thus be pleased to know that the SDU is pro-active, and will be rolling out a funding scheme by the new academic year, called Project Network to co-fund student bodies' activities aimed at promoting gender interaction and relationship-building skills.

    Some years ago, Mr Eddie Teo, Permanent Secretary in the Prime Minister's Office, was asked what he would like to say about the President's scholarship that he got. His last words on this were: Oxford was where I met my wife. A year or two later, when he was addressing a PSC seminar, he reminded the young crowd of potential scholars and their parents of the importance of balancing school and social life. He shared how he had bought a bicycle so that he could visit his wife, then his girlfriend, every day. His only lament was that the PSC refused to up his allowance, and thus he could only afford a pounds5 bicycle with no brakes and no lights! Perhaps, PSC knew better, for who needs a bright lamp when romance is in the air?

    I hope my fellow MPs will agree that socialising is indeed important, and it is important to balance school and social life, or work and social life. SDU and SDS

Column: 1854

help our singles get that balance. Given Dr Maliki's fervent interest in the subject, I hope I can count on his support and assistance to promote social activities in the university; so too Prof. Ngiam. Dr Jennifer Lee talked about the importance of institutions. I would call on the universities and institutes of higher learning to play an active role in facilitating social activities for their students. In fact, I would also urge all employers to play their part to help us address this national concern.

    Dr Lily Neo and Ms Irene Ng asked about childcare centres. They have indeed raised a highly pertinent point, for the availability and affordability of childcare are critical, if we are to encourage family formation. There are now 632 childcare centres providing 53,000 places, and the take-up rate is about 72%. Thus, there are enough places to meet demand at the moment. While we have plans this year to develop 50 more centres to provide an additional 3,500 places, we will only do so when the enrolment picks up. We will also encourage employers to set up workplace childcare centres but, ultimately, this will have to depend on demand.

    The childcare centre subsidy rate is currently $150 for working mothers who place their children in full-day care, and $75 for working mothers who place their children in half-day care. Non-working mothers who place their children in full or half-day care also enjoy a subsidy of $75. In this financial year, my Ministry has disbursed a total of $54 million of subsidies so far.

    I informed this Committee last year that my Ministry would look into a pro-rated childcare subsidy to mothers who need flexible childcare. I am happy to inform the Committee that my Ministry has introduced such a subsidy programme from January this year. As of 13th March 2003, 140 children are benefiting from the pro-rated subsidy.

    Dr Lily Neo and Ms Irene Ng have also spoken on infant care. I agree with them that more needs to be done to develop infant care. Presently, there are 13 infant

Column: 1855

care centres with 170 places. Centres that offer infant care have stricter requirements in terms of staff-child ratios. This is because babies need a greater amount of individual attention. Staff are also specially trained for infant care. Because of this, the fees for infant care range from $650 to $1,500, which are higher than the fees for the older age groups. My Ministry recognises that the childcare subsidy may be insufficient when compared to the infant care fees. While I have mentioned earlier that the baby bonus may also be used to offset the infant care fees, we are currently reviewing the situation to ensure that services remain affordable for parents.

    Ms Irene Ng mentioned that when she surveyed her constituency, she found that the demand for infant care centres was high. The waiting lists at the existing infant care centres are also testimony that centre-based care can be a suitable option for some families. Ms Ng will be pleased to know that MCDS is looking at how to increase the supply of infant care across the island.

    MCDS has no objection, should operators want to operate their centres round the clock, if this is to meet the needs of parents working night shifts and irregular work patterns. However, our regulations state that no one child should remain in the centre for 24 hours or more continuously. Members would agree with me that a childcare centre should not be operated as a residential institution for young children. My Ministry takes the view that no baby or pre-school child should remain in centre-based care for the better part of 24 hours on a regular basis. Home care, at least for part of the day, and the opportunity to bond with one consistent caregiver, preferably a parent, is in the best interest of babies and young children.

    Our approach is consistent with the practices observed in other developed countries. Thus far, my Ministry has not received any application for a 24-hour childcare centre licence. I assure the Committee that my Ministry will assess all

Column: 1856

applications carefully to prevent abuse, and that the developmental well-being of the children is not compromised.

    Sir, in addition to centre-based infant care, my Ministry has piloted the Family Day Care, which is home-based infant care with trained babysitters. This scheme allows housewives and retirees to care for babies or young children, and earn income in their own home. I believe Dr Lily Neo mentioned this yesterday. It could be a suitable option, particularly for infants and children under 18 months, as it provides care by one consistent caregiver in a home setting. Since my announcement last year that the scheme would be piloted by Southeast and Southwest CDCs, Northeast CDC has also joined in the pilot. So far, 600 care-providers and 300 parents have registered for this scheme. It is premature to consider accrediting the caregivers at this stage. However the three CDCs keep a record of those who have been trained.

    There are possibly many more models of care which can be explored to suit the needs of different parents. My Ministry welcomes more suggestions, and also encourages more organisations and enterprises to come up with innovative ideas and solutions to meet our childcare needs.

    Sir, many Members have asked also about what we are doing to strengthen families in Singapore. I will ask my Minister of State, Mr Chan Soo Sen, to respond to these questions later. Let me now turn to the subject of abandoned babies.

    I share the concerns of Ms Irene Ng, Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang and Mr Sin Boon Ann about the plight of abandoned babies. On average, five babies were abandoned each year from 1997 to 2002. Since January 2003, two babies were abandoned and two were found dead. Of the two dead, we know for sure that one of them was stillborn; the Coroner's report on the second is still pending. Notwithstanding these clarifications, I share Members' concern that babies are involved. This is a highly emotive issue,

Column: 1857

and there are no easy answers. What we all share is that we want babies to be safe, and we also want to help the mothers as well. Indeed, our hearts go out to the babies and their mothers. The question is how to help both of them effectively.

    Firstly, pregnant women in distress can seek help. They must be aware that, if they come forward and say that they are unable to keep their babies, they will not be prosecuted for abandonment. We have a care and counselling system that has prevented desperate acts of endangering a baby's well-being. This system has worked. Last year, 515 enquiries on pregnancy issues were received through the hotlines. Of these, 33 pregnant women were helped at the shelters, 19 later gave up their babies for adoption, while the rest were helped to keep their babies. In assisting the pregnant women, the social workers walk through all the options with them, and support them all the way. This will ensure that the well-being of both the baby and the mother is taken care of.

    Secondly, Sir, there is a role for the community. Pregnancy takes nine months. A woman cannot go about her life unnoticed. Those around her can and should encourage her and even accompany her to come forward for help. Whatever the circumstances she faces, abandonment can never be the solution. She could alert someone, even a stranger, to hand over the child, if she cannot take care of the baby.

    Publicity about the help is also very important. Even countries that have tried safe havens or baby drops, have not been able to stop abandonment and related deaths, either because the mothers are in no frame of mind to use such baby drops, or because they were not aware of them. Ours is an approach that seeks to help both the mother and the baby. Of course, it is best for women to seek assistance early, before the birth of a baby but, even if they do not, we can still help them after the delivery, if they feel unable to keep their child. It is never too late to come forward for help.

Column: 1858



    We need to further publicise the system and, especially, the helplines and hotlines for pregnant women in distress. In this regard, my Ministry has made 24-hour helpline numbers readily available at the notice boards of Residents Committee centres. This is the flyer that we have put up in all the Residents Committee centres [indicating]. Anyone who is facing problems and needs support should tap into the care and counselling system. Confidentiality is assured for all who come forward for help, and we will increase our publicity efforts.

    There have been calls for legislative changes and to set up baby drops. Both Mr Sin Boon Ann and Ms Irene Ng have said that it is not for us to judge the morality of the parents who dump their children. Let me assure them again that if mothers come forward, they will not be prosecuted for abandonment. That is key. Let me also say that it is not so much a question of morality as much as it is a concern that we will inadvertently endanger the lives of more babies, if we legalise abandonment. By lifting the inalienable responsibility of parents to care for and protect their children, we risk the safety and lives of many more babies and children. Moreover, there is no evidence to suggest that, by legalising abandonment at baby drops, desperate acts, such as the recent instance where a baby was found with the umbilical cord intact, would be stopped.

    Today, we have a system where those who step forward early are supported by social workers and given shelter, if necessary. There are many instances where both mother and baby have been helped this way and have moved on with their lives. The system does not discriminate, and will help all those who come forward, local or foreign alike. I assure Members that the help is given with great sensitivity and, in really desperate situations, nothing will compromise the safety and health of mother and child. Contrary to what Ms Irene Ng thought, I can assure her that there is no obsession about obtaining the biological information of the mother. The priority must always be the safety of the mother

Column: 1859

and the child. In fact, we walk her through the process and allow her, at her own time and own pace, to give us whatever information that she is prepared to share with us.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann has alluded to the point that for baby drops to be effective, they have to be easily accessible and known to those who are likely to use them. Sir, based on my staff's consultations with their American counterparts, the US experience continues to be contentious as to whether baby drops are a good approach or whether publicity focusing on engaging pregnant girls early in their pregnancy might be a safer approach for both the mother and baby. For baby drops to work, almost every front door has to be a potential baby drop, as those in desperation will not be in any frame of mind to go to designated places. That is why the role of the community and the public is important.

    Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, I would like to thank the Members who have spoken on a matter that is close to our hearts - caring for our aged and preparing for an ageing population.

    Let me first address the point raised by Ms Braema Mathiaparanam. As Ms Braema Mathiaparanam has pointed out, there are certain segments of our population who are less financially secure. In general, women may need more retirement savings as they tend to live longer than men. For women who have less capacity and opportunity to accumulate financial resources, for example, housewives from low income families with no CPF accounts, the low-income, or lower-educated singles and divorced women, it is even more important for them to develop adequate means and resources to support themselves in their retirement years. Work is still the best form of welfare. And for those who are unable to support themselves, our social safety net schemes would help them.

    She has asked whether or not we have done a study on how our women are coping. I cannot say for certain that we have done a particular study in this area. But part of the IMC focus is to understand how Singaporeans, in general, including single women who are older, cope with the financial demands of their retirement age.

    My Ministry is aware that there may be women who need help in coping especially with the impact of economic restructuring. In fact, we have begun dialogues with the three key women's organisations, namely, the Singapore Council of Women's Organisations, the NTUC Women's Committee and the PA Women Integration Network (WIN). The aim, as I said earlier, is to try and help our women folks to explore what are the collaborative opportunities in training and re-skilling of women in areas, such as IT

and domestic services. So the long-term goal is to give them some skills so that they can find jobs and develop some financial independence. So I would like to assure Ms Braema that we will look into this matter as part of our effort to understand better how Singaporeans are coping in their retirement age. In this regard, the services that are needed will be put in place as and when there are service gaps.

    Ms Irene Ng spoke about the need to educate our young about supporting their aged parents. Filial responsibility has and will continue to underpin our philosophy of the "family as the first line of support". With an ageing population, smaller families and a rising dependency ratio, we must continue to reinforce these social values.

    Since 1994, we have been strongly promoting the Singapore Family Values, one of which is filial responsibility. These values are taught in the Civics and Moral Education, a compulsory subject for our primary and secondary students, and Civics at pre-university level.

    MCDS also undertakes a year-round public education drive to foster positive attitudes towards family and older persons. As part of this effort, we are also stressing strong inter-generational ties and the need to care for our elderly parents, not just their physical and financial needs but also seeing to their emotional and social needs. And Mr Chan Soo Sen has alluded to the Grand Parenting Day that we have started a couple of years ago.

    The Government has, over the years, introduced tax reliefs and other schemes to encourage Singaporeans to take care of their parents. These schemes include the parent relief, relief for CPF top-up of parents' retirement account and the use of Medisave savings to pay for the

Column: 1881

parents' hospital bills. Our housing policies encourage Singaporeans to live with or near their parents, and Ms Irene Ng would be pleased to learn that close to 88% of our seniors still live with their families.

    For the few who do not provide for their parents, the Maintenance of Parents Act provides a legal recourse for the aged parents to seek financial maintenance from these children.

    Sir, while we promote filial piety, we also empathise with families that are struggling to cope with the demands of caregiving. A few MPs have called for more to be done to help our elderly.

    Let me assure the House that my Ministry has invested substantially on eldercare and developmental programmes. In fact, our expenditure in this area has more than doubled over the past four years.

    Sir, Dr Jennifer Lee has asked for an update of the Eldercare Master Plan. Briefly, 86% of the recommendations would be implemented and we are looking into launching a new round of policy deliberations. At the next round of deliberations, we will focus on employment and sectoral needs, especially single elderly, both male and female, and what are the things that we need to do to help them so that they can continue to age actively in Singapore.

    Sir, as I said earlier, many of the programmes are already in place. For example, we have revised the funding norms to give the VWOs more resources to run programmes, such as day care, befriending and counselling services. Six new day care centres have been set up over the past two years. There are now more support and resources for caregivers, through a caregiver centre and the availability of carers' manuals.

    Apart from setting up facilities, we have made efforts to develop new capabilities in anticipation of future needs, such as gero-counselling and upgrading the skills

Column: 1882

of our aged care workers to enable them to deliver a higher quality of service. I have mentioned some of these initiatives yesterday, for example, developing bite-sized eldercare training courses under the National Skills Recognition System.

    I also like to allude to the point that Dr Jennifer Lee has mentioned about the IMC and whether or not we have been making headway. Sir, one significant breakthrough is that our policies now facilitate the entry of more players into the eldercare industry. This will gradually grow the pool of service providers and the variety of services, hence providing more choices to users. Active aging is still the cornerstone of our philosophy for the elderly. Initiatives include the Active Seniors Programme which has involved 1,200 senior volunteers. We also have nine Neighbourhood Links located in different parts of the island, which encourage inter-generational interaction and mutual help. So these are opportunities which we have created on the ground for the elderly to remain together with the community.

    A third breakthrough is that starting from April this year, my Ministry will be funding community case management service as a national programme. This is a significant development as it would pave the way for better coordination of community care for our older people. The service has been piloted locally and over 97% of the caregivers surveyed have found the service to be beneficial. This service provides a one-stop entry point for frail elderly who have multiple and

Column: 1883

complex needs. Case managers will assess the elderly's needs and put together a package of appropriate services and continue to monitor the progress of the individual.     Sir, a much needed breakthrough is in terms of employer mindset in hiring older workers. We will work with the Ministry of Manpower and other partners to address this issue, but there is a need for employers to do their part. In this regard, I commend the KK Women's and Children's Hospital and Dr Lee for being a fine example in this respect.

The centre is expected to be ready by the end of 2004. We will study the benefits of this pilot before expanding the concept to other housing estates.

    Not all our seniors have families to turn to, and Ms Irene Ng has touched on the needs of one such group - the elderly singles. Our programmes, such as befriending and home help, have succeeded in reaching out to some of

Column: 1884

these individuals, offering them much needed social and emotional support. Notwithstanding this, we agree that more could be done, particularly for those living alone.

    Sir, in this regard, we are working towards strengthening the community support network for this group, through developing a manual that will guide agencies on the action to take when they encounter such individuals and how to link them to support services in the community, such as the Neighbourhood Link and the Befriending Service. We agree with Dr Lee that the emphasis must first be on finding workable solutions for the family and not a punitive, legalistic approach.     Any elderly person requiring help can access services through a number of contact points, including the Family Service Centres, GPs, community agencies, MCDS or the hospitals.     Sir, the initiatives I have mentioned are part of our overall strategy to prepare

Column: 1885

Singapore for the challenges of an ageing population. Our approach is threefold - promoting personal responsibility through public education, creating opportunities for our seniors to contribute and play a role, and strengthening our eldercare services to help families cope with caregiving. The challenges are multi-faceted and require a coordinated effort not just among the Government agencies, but also among all sectors of the society.     Sir, yesterday we heard about the start of Gulf War II. We have talked about the

Column: 1887

devastating impact of terrorism on people. Yet, for generations, another form of terrorism has been taking place in our midst, ie, terrorism in our homes. Domestic violence, which encompasses psychological and physical terrorism, has a debilitating effect on the family. The 1997 amendment to the Women's Charter has opened doors for victims and their families to seek help.

    We also know that the first source of help for the victims of violence is the police. I must applaud MCDS and the Singapore Police Force for spearheading the National Family Violence Police Networking System, which allows victims needing help to go to Family Service Centres. This system has been in place for five years. I would like to know what is the extent of the problem now. How many incidents of violence have been reported to the police in the last five years? I have heard that, when incidents of violence occur and families call the police for assistance, there is a tendency for some police officers to downplay the violence, because they perceive it as a private domestic quarrel. In this regard, I would like to ask what is the police protocol with regard to handling domestic violence cases. Even with the protocol in place, what is being done by way of monitoring to ensure that these protocols are being adhered to?

    Sir, my concern is that victims of violence are already being disempowered. It takes a great deal of courage and will for them to seek help. When attempts of help are thwarted by well-intentioned officers, who sometimes confuse family violence with marital and family disputes, it is harder for the victims to come forward again. Some clients actually tell social workers that abusers tell them that it is no point seeking help, as no one would believe them.

    Sir, all they are asking for is for the violence to stop, not for the relationship to end. Perhaps, this message needs to be stressed to the very people whose mandate is to stop violence, ie, the police.

Column: 1888

Thus, my question is: how does MCDS work with the police in ensuring that cases of domestic violence receive appropriate and immediate attention? What are the legal obligations of the police to help?

    Sir, this is critical in repeated cases of abuse that we see - because of what is known as the "battered women" syndrome, ie, the sense of helplessness or the fear of further abuse to them and their children - many of these victims are extremely fearful to seek help. I would like to ask the Minister how are such cases helped. Would MCDS consider a system like the one in Australia where, in very serious cases of domestic abuse, the police can apply what is known as an interim protection order?

    Sir, in the case of child abuse, there are laws to remove children from abusive homes. In cases of violence in the home, eg, in cases of elder-abuse, spousal violence, are there laws that give the police the mandate to remove adults from their homes when they are abused?

    Sir, from time to time, we hear of cases of victims in cohabitative relationships being abused. While they can seek private summonses, there is no formal protection accorded to them. How is domestic violence with regard to such couples handled? MCDS has indicated that it is going to look into this matter. I would like to ask what is the status of the situation now. In the light of the recent murder cases involving couples who have resorted to the most extreme form of violence - and some of them are in cohabitative relationships - does MCDS plan to deal with violence in an intimate relationship?

    Sir, whatever the reasons, violence can and should never be condoned. It is our moral responsibility not only to respect but to protect the dignity of individuals and families from abuse. The world may be turbulent, and war may be going on as we speak. We must continue to strive for peace. Let peace begin within the four walls of our homes.

    As we deal with domestic violence, there is what is called a personal protection

Column: 1889

order (PPO), which can be taken up by victims to protect themselves from further abuse. It is an instrument and an avenue for them in this regard. I would like to ask the Minister how many personal protection orders have been issued to victims of abuse in the last five years and, if the trend is increasing, whatever the reasons may be, will greater resources be allocated in addressing this trend?

    Sir, violence does not occur once. There is such a thing that is called the cycle of violence. Thus, many of the victims are protected by PPOs from further abuse. However, because violence occurs again, there is what is called a breach of PPOs. I would like to ask how many cases of PPOs have been breached. How does the police determine a breach? I ask these questions because I know of many situations where victims are told by the courts and their social workers that, should a breach occur, all they need to do is to call the police. However, when they seek police assistance, they perceive that no action is taken although, according to documents given to them in court, a breach has occurred. It is even harder for them when psychological abuse takes place in the form of threats and harassment, as these are often difficult to prove.

However, I would like to know what happens when a person breaches an order, ie, what kind of action is taken when a breach occurs. In the most recent year, what is the breakdown of the different kinds of action taken for breach cases? As one of the key stakeholders of the National Family Violence Networking System, what is MCDS' position or policy on breach cases? How does it work with the police in this regard?

Column: 1890

the law and, when someone breaks the law, there are punishments to be meted out. Thus, the issue of breach of PPOs is important, because we need to send the message to both victims and perpetrators that the law has to be respected. The actions of the relevant agencies, eg, the police and MCDS, must also reflect this very same message.

    I am also aware that, with issues of interpersonal violence, getting the cooperation of victims when action is taken is sometimes difficult, as victims do back out. This is expected, as no one wants the member of the family to be convicted. However, we also need to keep in mind that reporting a person for breaking the law is not - and I stress, is not - about breaking up the family. It is about stopping violence and, as I mentioned earlier, we want to stop abuse and help families rebuild their relationships. By doing so, we can keep the family unit intact.

    1) How many counselling orders have been issued in the last five years?

    2) For each of the five years, what is the proportion of counselling orders issued to the number of personal protection orders issued?

    3) Is this seen as an acceptable proportion?

firstly, the trend in domestic violence in the last five years; secondly, how Police handle domestic violence; and thirdly, how cases of non-spousal violence are handled.

    Sir, between 1998 and 2002, the number of Personal Protection Order (PPO) applications averaged 2,866 cases per year. More than half (about 52%) are issued with PPOs.     Historically, environmental health, quarantine and epidemiology, which include infectious disease surveillance and the investigation of outbreaks, were carried out by MOH. When the Ministry was

These functions were taken over by the National Environment Agency (NEA) when it was formed on 1st July 2002.

    Currently, the surveillance and control of infectious diseases are shared between MOH and NEA. Their responsibilities are divided according to the type of disease. Diseases like typhoid fever and hand, foot and mouth disease come under NEA. But tuberculosis and HIV AIDS are under the purview of MOH. The current system works reasonably well for the surveillance and control of known diseases, for which the division of work between MOH and ENV is well established. However, we need to develop new expertise to deal with new dangers from communicable diseases.

    At present, almost similar expertise is being developed and deployed in the two Ministries for the surveillance and control of diseases under their respective purview.
